entities.description: Liang Qichao was a Chinese social and political activist, journalist, and intellectual who lived during the late Qing dynasty and the early Republic of China. His thought had a significant influence on the political reformation of modern China. He inspired Chinese scholars and activists with his writings and reform movements. His translations of Western and Japanese books into Chinese introduced n

heading: Deaths
txt: Frank P. Ramsey, British mathematician, philosopher and economist (b. 1903)

entities.title: Frank P. Ramsey
entities.description: Frank Plumpton Ramsey was a British philosopher, mathematician, and economist who made major contributions to all three fields before his death at the age of 26. He was a close friend of Ludwig Wittgenstein and, as an undergraduate, translated Wittgenstein’s Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus into English. He was also influential in persuading Wittgenstein to return to philosophy and Cambridge. Like W

heading: Deaths
txt: Branislav Nušić, Serbian author, playwright, and journalist (b. 1864)

entities.title: Branislav Nušić
entities.description: Branislav Nušić was a Serbian playwright, satirist, essayist, novelist and founder of modern rhetoric in Serbia. He also worked as a journalist and a civil servant. He was often referred to as the Serbian and Balkan Gogol.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gustave Mesny, French general (b. 1886)

entities.title: Gustave Mesny
entities.description: Gustave Marie Maurice Mesny was a French Army general in command of the 5th North African Infantry Division who was captured during the Second World War. Mesny was unlawfully executed in retribution for the death of German general Fritz von Brodowski.

heading: Deaths
txt: Tony Garnier, French architect and urban planner, designed the Stade de Gerland (b. 1869)

entities.title: Tony Garnier (architect)
entities.description: Tony Garnier was a noted architect and city planner. He was most active in his hometown of Lyon. Garnier is considered the forerunner of 20th century French architects.

entities.title: Stade de Gerland
entities.description: The Stade de Gerland is a stadium in the city of Lyon, France which serves as home to Top 14 rugby club Lyon OU. It has a seating capacity of 35,000.

heading: Deaths
txt: Theodor Kaluza, German mathematician and physicist (b. 1885)

entities.title: Theodor Kaluza
entities.description: Theodor Franz Eduard Kaluza was a German mathematician and physicist known for the Kaluza–Klein theory, involving field equations in five-dimensional space-time. His idea that fundamental forces can be unified by introducing additional dimensions re-emerged much later in string theory.

heading: Deaths
txt: József Dudás, Romanian-Hungarian activist and politician (b. 1912)

entities.title: József Dudás
entities.description: József Dudás, a Hungarian politician and resistance fighter, was born in Marosvásárhely in Austria-Hungary.

heading: Deaths
txt: Clement Smoot, American golfer (b. 1884)

entities.title: Clement Smoot
entities.description: Clement Eyer Smoot was an American golfer who competed in the 1904 Summer Olympics. He was born in Illinois and died in Los Angeles, California. In 1904 he was part of the American team which won the gold medal. He finished 6th in this competition. In the individual competition he finished 22nd in the qualification and was eliminated in the first round of the match play.

heading: Deaths
txt: Firmin Lambot, Belgian cyclist (b. 1886)

entities.title: Firmin Lambot
entities.description: Firmin Lambot was a Belgian bicycle racer who twice won the Tour de France.

heading: Deaths
txt: Arnold Luhaäär, Estonian weightlifter (b. 1905)

entities.title: Arnold Luhaäär
entities.description: Arnold Luhaäär was an Estonian heavyweight weightlifter. He competed in the 1928 and 1936 Olympics and won a silver and a bronze medal, respectively. He missed the 1932 games because Estonia could not afford sending a full team to Los Angeles during the Great Depression.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ray Harroun, American race car driver and engineer (b. 1879)

entities.title: Ray Harroun
entities.description: Ray Harroun was an American racecar driver and pioneering constructor most famous for winning the inaugural Indianapolis 500 in 1911.

heading: Deaths
txt: Michael Rabin, American violinist (b. 1936)

entities.title: Michael Rabin (violinist)
entities.description: Michael Rabin was an American violinist. He has been described as "one of the most talented and tragic violin virtuosi of his generation". His complete Paganini "24 Caprices" for solo violin are available as a single CD, and an additional 6-CD set contains most of his concerto recordings. Despite his brief career—he died at 35—they remain seminal interpretations.

heading: Deaths
txt: Max Adrian, Irish-English actor (b. 1903)

entities.title: Max Adrian
entities.description: Max Adrian was an Irish stage, film and television actor and singer. He was a founding member of both the Royal Shakespeare Company and the National Theatre.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Hart Benton, American painter and educator (b. 1889)

entities.title: Thomas Hart Benton (painter)
entities.description: Thomas Hart Benton was an American painter and muralist. Along with Grant Wood and John Steuart Curry, he was at the forefront of the Regionalist art movement. The fluid, sculpted figures in his paintings showed everyday people in scenes of life in the United States. His work is strongly associated with the Midwestern United States, the region in which he was born and which he called home for most

heading: Deaths
txt: Hidetsugu Yagi, Japanese engineer and academic (b. 1886)

entities.title: Hidetsugu Yagi
entities.description: Hidetsugu Yagi  was a Japanese electrical engineer from Osaka, Japan. When working at Tohoku University, he wrote several articles that introduced a new antenna designed by his colleague Shintaro Uda to the English-speaking world.

heading: Deaths
txt: Moritz Jahn, German novelist and poet (b. 1884)

entities.title: Moritz Jahn
entities.description: Moritz Jahn was a Lower German novelist and an educator. He was also a poet, best known for writing poetry as well such as ballad, lyric, and narratives. Jahn was born in Lilienthal, a suburb in Lower Saxony to a Low German family. He was the member for Nazi Party. He has written notable books with narration such as Frangula and Lucifer. He was active from the 1920s to 1950s.

heading: Deaths
txt: William O. Douglas, American lawyer and jurist (b. 1898)

entities.title: William O. Douglas
entities.description: William Orville Douglas was an American jurist and politician who served as an associate justice of the Supreme Court of the United States. Nominated by President Franklin D. Roosevelt, Douglas was confirmed at the age of 40, one of the youngest justices appointed to the court. His term, lasting 36 years and 211 days (1939–75), is the longest in the history of the Supreme Court. In 1975, Time maga

heading: Deaths
txt: Francesca Woodman, American photographer (b. 1958)

entities.title: Francesca Woodman
entities.description: Francesca Stern Woodman was an American photographer best known for her black and white pictures featuring either herself or female models.

heading: Deaths
txt: Elis Regina, Brazilian soprano (b. 1945)

entities.title: Elis Regina
entities.description: Elis Regina Carvalho Costa, known professionally as Elis Regina, was a Brazilian singer of popular and jazz music, she is also the mother of the singers Maria Rita and Pedro Mariano.

heading: Deaths
txt: Max Bentley, Canadian ice hockey player and coach (b. 1920)

entities.title: Max Bentley
entities.description: Maxwell Herbert Lloyd "Max" Bentley was a Canadian ice hockey forward who played for the Chicago Blackhawks, Toronto Maple Leafs, and New York Rangers in the National Hockey League (NHL) as part of a professional and senior career that spanned 20 years. He was the NHL's leading scorer twice in a row, and in 1946 won the Hart Trophy as most valuable player. He played in four All-Star Games and was

heading: Deaths
txt: Lawrence Kohlberg, American psychologist and academic (b. 1927)

entities.title: Lawrence Kohlberg
entities.description: Lawrence Kohlberg was an American psychologist best known for his theory of stages of moral development.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, Indian guru and mystic (b. 1931)

entities.title: Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh
entities.description: Rajneesh, also known as Acharya Rajneesh, Bhagwan Shri Rajneesh, Bhagwan Rajneesh, Osho Rajneesh and later as Osho, was an Indian godman, mystic, and founder of the Rajneesh movement.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alberto Semprini, English pianist, composer, and conductor (b. 1908)

heading: Deaths
txt: Herbert Wehner, German politician, 6th Minister of Intra-German Relations (b. 1906)

entities.title: Minister of Intra-German Relations
entities.description: The Federal Minister of Intra-German Relations was a federal cabinet minister of the Federal Republic of Germany. The office was created under the title of Federal Minister of All-German Affairs in 1949, being also in charge of the German lands east of the Oder–Neisse line which had been put under Polish or Soviet administration. In 1951, the first Minister of All-German Affairs Jakob Kaiser openl

heading: Deaths
txt: Marcel Chaput, Canadian biochemist and journalist (b. 1918)

entities.title: Marcel Chaput
entities.description: Marcel Chaput was a scientist and a militant for the independence of Quebec from Canada. Along with some 20 other people including André D'Allemagne and Jacques Bellemare, he was a founding member of the Rassemblement pour l'indépendance nationale (RIN).

heading: Deaths
txt: Gene MacLellan, Canadian singer-songwriter (b. 1938)

entities.title: Gene MacLellan
entities.description: Gene MacLellan was a Canadian singer-songwriter from Prince Edward Island. Among his compositions were "Snowbird", made famous by Anne Murray, "Put Your Hand in the Hand", "The Call", "Pages of Time" and "Thorn in My Shoe". Elvis Presley, Lynn Anderson, Loretta Lynn, Joan Baez, and Bing Crosby were among the many artists who recorded MacLellan's songs.

heading: Deaths
txt: Don Simpson, American actor, producer, and screenwriter (b. 1943)

entities.title: Don Simpson
entities.description: Donald Clarence Simpson was an American film producer, screenwriter, and actor. Simpson and his producing partner Jerry Bruckheimer produced such hit films as Flashdance (1983), Beverly Hills Cop (1984), Top Gun (1986), and The Rock (1996). Their films earned $3 billion worldwide.

heading: Deaths
txt: James Dickey, American poet and novelist (b. 1923)

heading: Deaths
txt: Carl Perkins, American singer-songwriter and guitarist (b. 1932)

entities.title: Carl Perkins
entities.description: Carl Lee Perkins was an American singer-songwriter who recorded most notably at the Sun Studio, in Memphis, beginning in 1954. Amongst his best-known songs are "Blue Suede Shoes", "Matchbox" and "Everybody's Trying to Be My Baby".

heading: Deaths
txt: Ivan Francescato, Italian rugby player (b. 1967)

entities.title: Ivan Francescato
entities.description: Ivan Francescato was an Italian rugby union player.

heading: Deaths
txt: Amatu'l-Bahá Rúhíyyih Khánum, a Baháʼí Faith Hand of the Cause of God and wife of Shoghi Effendi (b. 1910)

entities.title: Rúhíyyih Khanum
entities.description: Rúhíyyih Rabbání, born as Mary Sutherland Maxwell and best known by the title Amatu'l-Bahá Rúhíyyih Khánum, was the wife of Shoghi Effendi, the Guardian of the Baháʼí Faith from 1921 to 1957. In 1952, she was elevated to the office of Hand of the Cause of God, for which she attended to issues related to the expansion and protection of the Baháʼí Faith, and served an important role in the transfer

entities.title: Baháʼí Faith
entities.description: The Baháʼí Faith is a new religion teaching the essential worth of all religions and the unity of all people. Established by Baháʼu'lláh in the 19th century, it initially developed in Persia and parts of the Middle East, where it has faced ongoing persecution since its inception. The religion is estimated to have over five million adherents, known as Baháʼís, spread throughout most of the world's

entities.title: Hands of the Cause
entities.description: The Hands of the Cause, or Hands (informally) was a title for an appointed position in the Baháʼí Faith. The position was appointed for life by the religion's founders, with the last one dying in 2007. Hands of the Cause played a significant role in propagating the religion, and protecting it from schism.

entities.title: Shoghi Effendi
entities.description: Shoghí Effendí was the grandson and successor of ʻAbdu'l-Bahá, appointed to the role of Guardian of the Baháʼí Faith from 1921 until his death in 1957. Shoghi Effendi created a series of teaching plans that oversaw the expansion of the faith to many new countries. He also translated and provided authoritative interpretation of many of the writings of the Baháʼí central figures. He was succeeded by

heading: Deaths
txt: Bettino Craxi, Italian lawyer and politician, 45th Prime Minister of Italy (b. 1934)

entities.title: Prime Minister of Italy
entities.description: The President of the Council of Ministers of the Italian Republic, commonly referred to in Italy as Presidente del Consiglio or informally as Premier, and known in English as the Prime Minister of Italy, is the head of government of the Italian Republic. The office of Prime Minister is established by Articles 92 through 96 of the Constitution of Italy. The Prime Minister is appointed by the Presid

heading: Deaths
txt: Hedy Lamarr, Austrian-American actress, singer, and mathematician (b. 1913)

heading: Deaths
txt: Dario Vittori, Italian-Argentinian actor and producer (b. 1921)

entities.title: Dario Vittori
entities.description: Darío Víttori was an Italian born Argentine comic actor. His real name was Melito Darío Spartaco Margozzi and was born on 14 September 1921 in Montecelio, Lazio, Italy. Died on 19 January 2001 in Buenos Aires, Argentina.

heading: Deaths
txt: Vavá, Brazilian footballer and manager (b. 1934)

entities.title: Vavá
entities.description: Edvaldo Jizídio Neto, commonly known as Vavá, was a Brazilian footballer who is widely considered one of the best strikers of his generation. His nickname was "Peito de Aço". He played as a main striker for Sport Club do Recife, C.R. Vasco da Gama, S.E. Palmeiras and the Brazil national football team.

heading: Deaths
txt: Milton Flores, Honduran footballer (b. 1974)

entities.title: Milton Flores
entities.description: Milton Javier Flores Miranda was a Honduran football player.

heading: Deaths
txt: Françoise Giroud, French journalist, screenwriter, and politician, French Minister of Culture (b. 1916)

entities.title: Minister of Culture (France)
entities.description: The Ministry of Culture is the ministry of the Government of France in charge of national museums and the monuments historiques. Its goal is to maintain the French identity through the promotion and protection of the arts on national soil and abroad. Its budget is mainly dedicated to the management of the Archives Nationales and the regional Maisons de la culture.

heading: Deaths
txt: Harry E. Claiborne, American lawyer and judge (b. 1917)

entities.title: Harry E. Claiborne
entities.description: Harry Eugene Claiborne was a United States District Judge of the United States District Court for the District of Nevada from 1978 until his impeachment and removal in 1986. Appointed by President Jimmy Carter in 1978, Claiborne was only the fifth person in United States history to be removed from office through impeachment by the United States Congress and the first since Halsted Ritter in 1936.

heading: Deaths
txt: David Hookes, Australian cricketer and coach (b. 1955)

heading: Deaths
txt: K. Sello Duiker, South African author and screenwriter (b. 1974)

entities.title: K. Sello Duiker
entities.description: Kabelo Sello Duiker was a South African novelist. His debut novel, Thirteen Cents, won the 2001 Commonwealth Writers Prize for Best First Book, Africa Region. His second novel, The Quiet Violence of Dreams, won the 2002 Herman Charles Bosman Prize. He also worked in advertising and as a screenwriter.

heading: Deaths
txt: Anthony Franciosa, American actor (b. 1928)

entities.title: Anthony Franciosa
entities.description: Anthony Franciosa was an American actor.

entities.title: Hrant Dink
entities.description: Hrant Dink was a Turkish-Armenian intellectual, editor-in-chief of Agos, journalist and columnist.

heading: Deaths

heading: Deaths

entities.title: Suzanne Pleshette
entities.description: Suzanne Pleshette was an American theatre, film, television, and voice actress. Pleshette started her career in the theatre and began appearing in films in the late 1950s and later appeared in prominent films such as Rome Adventure (1962) and Alfred Hitchcock's The Birds (1963). She later appeared in various television productions, often in guest roles, and played Emily Hartley on The Bob Newhart

heading: Deaths
txt: John Stewart, American singer-songwriter and guitarist (b. 1939)

heading: Deaths
txt: Don Wittman, Canadian sportscaster (b. 1936)

heading: Deaths
txt: Bill McLaren, Scottish rugby player and sportscaster (b. 1923)

entities.title: Bill McLaren
entities.description: William Pollock McLaren was a Scottish rugby union commentator, teacher, journalist and one time rugby player. Known as 'the voice of rugby', he retired from commentating in 2002. Renowned throughout the sport, his enthusiasm and memorable turn of phrase endeared him to many.

heading: Deaths
txt: Peter Åslin, Swedish ice hockey player (b. 1962)

entities.title: Peter Åslin
entities.description: Peter Karl Åslin was a Swedish national team ice hockey goaltender.

heading: Deaths
txt: Rudi van Dantzig, Dutch ballet dancer and choreographer (b. 1933)

heading: Deaths
txt: Taihō Kōki, Japanese sumo wrestler, the 48th Yokozuna (b. 1940)

entities.title: Taihō Kōki
entities.description: Taihō Kōki  was a Japanese professional sumo wrestler. He became the 48th yokozuna in 1961 at the age of 21, the youngest ever at the time.

entities.title: Makuuchi
entities.description: Makuuchi (幕内), or makunouchi (幕の内), is the top division of the six divisions of professional sumo. Its size is fixed at 42 wrestlers (rikishi), ordered into five ranks according to their ability as defined by their performance in previous tournaments.

heading: Deaths
txt: Azaria Alon, Ukrainian-Israeli environmentalist, co-founded the Society for the Protection of Nature in Israel (b. 1918)

entities.title: Azaria Alon
entities.description: Azaria Alon was an Israel Prize-winning environmentalist, and a co-founder of the Society for the Protection of Nature in Israel (SPNI).

entities.title: Society for the Protection of Nature in Israel
entities.description: Society for the Protection of Nature in Israel, or SPNI, is an Israeli non-profit environmental organization working to preserve plants, animals, and natural environments that represent bio-diversity, by protecting the lands and waters needed for their survival, and is Israel's oldest and largest conservation organization.

heading: Deaths
txt: Christopher Chataway, English runner, journalist, and politician (b. 1931)

heading: Deaths
txt: Justin Capră, Romanian engineer and academic (b. 1933)

entities.title: Justin Capră
entities.description: Virgilius Justin Capră was a Romanian engineer and inventor.

heading: Deaths
txt: Richard Levins, American ecologist and geneticist (b. 1930)

entities.title: Richard Levins
entities.description: Richard "Dick" Levins was an ex-tropical farmer turned ecologist, a population geneticist, biomathematician, mathematical ecologist, and philosopher of science who researched diversity in human populations. Until his death, Levins was a university professor at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health and a long-time political activist. He was best known for his work on evolution and complexit

txt: Ettore Scola, Italian director and screenwriter (b. 1931)

heading: Deaths
txt: Sheila Sim, English actress (b. 1922)

heading: Deaths
txt: Miguel Ferrer, American actor (b. 1955)

entities.title: Miguel Ferrer
entities.description: Miguel José Ferrer was an American actor. His breakthrough role was in the 1987 film RoboCop. Other film roles include Quigley in Blank Check (1994), Harbinger in Hot Shots! Part Deux (1993), Shan Yu in Mulan (1998), Eduardo Ruiz in Traffic (2000) and Vice President Rodriguez in Iron Man 3 (2013).
